caseTitle: THE 1992 CONSTITUTION, CHALLENGES AND PROSPECTS [1993-95] VO
summary: This article by Hon. Mr. Justice N.Y.B. Adade, a Justice of the Supreme Court of Ghana, examines the philosophical foundations and practical challenges of the 1992 Constitution, emphasizing its lineage from the 1969 and 1979 Constitutions. The author highlights the intent to diffuse executive power and prevent authoritarianism following the collapse of previous democratic experiments. The Constitution is affirmed as the supreme law under Article 1(2), with all other laws subject to its provisions. Article 2 empowers individuals to challenge unconstitutional acts in the Supreme Court, though public awareness and judicial enforcement remain critical. The piece calls for greater civic and legal education, particularly regarding human rights protections, and urges the legal profession to proactively safeguard constitutional rights in everyday contexts such as police conduct, press freedom, fair trial rights, and access to information.

judges.name: N.Y.B. Adade

rationaleHighlights: The 1992 Constitution is the supreme law, rendering inconsistent laws void.
Constitutional enforcement requires active litigation, not passive public awareness.
Diffusion of power is central to preventing authoritarianism.
Legal professionals have a duty to educate the public on constitutional rights.
Human dignity and fair treatment, especially in custody, are constitutionally protected.
Access to information and press freedom are implied constitutional rights.
The right to fair trial extends beyond criminal cases to civil proceedings.
Public demonstrations and counter-demonstrations must respect constitutional freedoms.
